boat.name: Kingfisher of Hamford Water
boat.full_description:
Designed by Charles Nicholson and Uffa Fox, 'Kingfisher' was built in the 1930s at Chatham Naval Dockyard, probably one of the last sailing vessels they ever built there. She served at HMS Ganges, Shotley, then moved to the Royal Hospital School in the mid 1970s, after Ganges station closed. She was used for training in a fleet of 10 RNSA 14’ dinghies. The RNSA fleet was sold in 1978-79 with at least eight boats going to a hire firm at Felixstowe. She was purchased from the Bosun and kept at the Colonel’s hard on the Twizzle, which was later to become Titchmarsh Marina.

RNSA's like Kingfisher are rare now. Many were burnt at Plymouth when the Navy turned to GRP Bosun dinghies in the 1970s.

Charles Harrison purchased her in 2003 and completed her restoration, taking her to the Brest and Douarnenez Festivals in 2004 and sailing her in Chichester Harbour and the Solent. Since then she has been kept under cover.

She retains many original features, including superb bronze fittings that would make I K Brunel whistle. Peppered with crowsfeet and Chatham marks on every surface, her beautiful Egyptian cotton sails have Chatham sail loft marks, made in the 1960s.
boat.construction_details: Clinker built, probably mahogany on oak, copper fastened. Bronze fittings including centreplate winch.
boat.short_description: Kingfisher of Hamford Water is a sailing dinghy, probably one of the last sailing vessels built at Chatham Naval Dockyard.
